To clarify: I'm not attacking any teacher seconded to @JCforTeachers. I know many of you and I know you all to be professionals dedicated to the betterment of student learning and, indeed, teacher learning. I'm directing my points at those unwilling to change the specification
The elements that make up the portfolio up to the teacher. Doesn't have to contain an essay. The AT that tests the portfolio can be bluffed. That's the reality.

The reality, on the ground, in the classroom, is that if you put all of these elements together, add in pressure from parents and Principals pushing you to ensure your students achieve a high grade, then something will give. I have heard many teachers say that it is the essay.
How many forms of writing are there? How many purposes are there? Now put the two together and work out the amount of combinations.

Emer. You are correct in saying that these two LOs are directing us to teach writing but neither of them states how long that writing must be. Indeed they both ask us to teach the impossible. How can I complete such vague outcomes? https://t.co/HX1NCkl0dQ

The @NCCAie need to be very careful before they mess with a system that, for the most part, works. The Junior Cycle has been a disaster for my subject, I don't want the Leaving Cert to go the same way (LC English works pretty well these days, mainly because of how the Qs r worded

I like the idea of continuous assessment but when the result is tied to whether your child gets into the course they want in college this system will be corrupted almost immediately. (I'd love for students to be able to work on a story for a few months for their LC)
As for inexperienced examiners... Dear god. Really? Does anyone want an inexperienced plasterer, doctor, tiler, hairdresser etc doing work for them?

And modules that include 'life skills' of their choice and extracurricular credits? Will this be a reward for charitable activities? Will they be able to get credit for coaching the local under 8s? Or will mummy and daddy get their friends to say that they did the above?

Now think about what will happen with continuous assessment. Will it be liberate the students? Will the students be able to fully explore their learning? Or will those with money buy the answers off the Internet? Or maybe write and rewrite their answers with the help of a grind?
Now, let's remind ourselves of the current LC landscape: Those with the cash get grinds and extra tuition. Websites sell notes and sample answers. Those without money don't access the above.
The Leaving Cert is under review and the suggestions are as expected: Continuous assessment (corrected by inexperienced examiners ['cause they're cheap]) and modules. https://t.co/4DVlPLih8Q
